body.p:
Louisville Ky
Sept 26. 1863
Gov Bramlett Esqr
Frankfort KY
Dear Sir

Enclosed I send you the petition of John Galvin and many citizens praying that John Galvin be relieved of the fine imposed upon him by the City Court. I have no interest in this matter beyond that of any other of the citizens who join Galvin in asking the remission of the fine

I have been interested so far in this case as to ask you to remit this fine because Galvin is a poor, industrious, honest man. Harper may also be poor, but he is dissipated reckless & worthless; and further because this trouble grew out of political toubles between Galvin & Harper, the first a good and staunch union man and the other a rebel; and be because, as I believe, had it not been for the conduct of Harper the difficulty would have never been. Mr Reasor the Prosecutor

petitions for the remission of half the fine, this I take it under all the circumstances surrounding the case is sufficient evidence that Executive clemency should intervene and the whole fine be remitted.
I trust, Governor, that you will remit the whole.

I am respectfully your Friend
Jos G. Watson
Should you remit the fine enclose &c &c to Jos Enders care of Severson & Enders at this city.
